sectionTitle: Some Aspects of Short-Term Financial Policy

columns.text: In this problem, we will answer questions that will check our understanding of net working capital.

The net working capital of a company provides an insight into their short-term financial health. It shows the difference between their current assets and current liabilities. A higher net working capital means that the company currently has more assets than liabilities which also translates to their short term financial health being good.

**a.)** A net working capital equal to zero means that the current liabilities and current assets of the firm are completely equal. This is an ideal scenario which means all factors should be perfect in order to achieve this scenario. 

The real world does not have this certain scenario because it is the discrepancies between the assets and liabilities that keep the market going as it creates opportunities to either make or lose money.
**b.)** Investing in assets is a way to generate more revenue in the long run. However, there is an optimal size that the firm should always keep in mind when investing in the current assets.

One way to determine this size is to evaluate the current sales based on the current assets. The optimal size is equal to this sales. We can consider the law of diminishing returns here which means if we exceed this investment size we will spend more money with little to no gain. On the other hand, investing less than this will limit the possible gains that the firm can have.

**c.)** As mentioned earlier, the net working capital measures a firm's short-term financial health. Developing either a flexible or a restrictive net working capital policy is key to maintain a good short-term financial health.

A restrictive short-term financial policy involves making only small investments in the firm's inventory as well as keeping only low amounts of cash balances. This type of policy gives a low ratio of current assets to the sales.

On the other hand, a flexible short-term financial policy gives a high ratio of current assets to sales since this type of policy uses more long-term debt than short-term debt, which means that there is more short-term cash available.
